moves.1. e4: Sometimes you show up overdressed for the party.  In this game, Mr. Kitrich wore a cummerbund to a camp fire.
moves.1... e5: I usually play D4, but a lot of my games have been drawish with symmetrical pawn structure.
moves.2. Nc3 Nf6 3. Nf3: I used to play the Four Knights, and I think this is the book line.
moves.3... Nc6 4. Bc4: The position takes on characteristics of the Giucco Piano.
moves.4... h6 5. d3 Bc5: My first idea is to exchange off his dark-squared bishop.
moves.6. Qe2 Ng4: Threatening the proverbially-weak f2 square.  In blitz you get a lot of players who prefer these arrogant attacks.  In the game, I estimate that I will be able to defend.
moves.7. Be3 d6: Nd4 might have been a better try.
moves.8. Bxc5 dxc5 9. h3 Nf6: I want to get a knight to the inviting d5 square.
moves.10... Nb4: Threatening Nxc2+.  Here I decided to sacrifice c2 and the exchange in return for a strong attacking position.
moves.11. O-O Nxc2 12. Qxc5: The immediate threat is Qxe5+.  I estimate that he will not allow me play it.
moves.12... Nxa1 13. Qxe5+ Be6 14. Bxe6 fxe6 1: White is down a rook, with 1 pawn for the exchange.  In this position it is imperative to keep black off balance, and unable to muster a defense.
moves.15... Qe7 16. Qc4 Nc2: In this sharp position, white shows the first hint of class.
moves.17. e5: E5 kicks the night, allowing me to play the compelling Nd5.
moves.17... Nd7 18. Nd5 Qc5: A convincing reply.  White must continue to keep the pressure up while managing to avoid simplifications.
moves.19. Qg4: A dubious sacrifice from white.  While white be able to regain face?
moves.19... Qxd5 20. Qg6+ Qf7 21. Qe4: White is down a rook and pawn, and the attack appears to be petering out.
moves.21... O-O-O 22. Rc1: Black still has a considerable advantage, with a seemingly-secure king position.  White's f3 knight appears listless.
moves.22... Nc5 23. Qe2 Nd4 24. Nxd4: And white is regaining some material.
moves.24... Rxd4 25. Rxc5 Qxa2: This looks materialistic and narrow-minded.  Black has undefended pieces and white's e5 pawn could be a liability.
moves.26. Qc2 Qa1+: Black's play is characterized by increasing thoughtlessness.
moves.27. Kh2 b6 28. Rxc7+ Kd8: In this critical position white chose e6 over the immediate rc8+ followed by ke7, qx7+,  and ke6.
moves.29. e6: The position is now critical for black.  His best try may have been Qa3 or Re8.
moves.29... Qa5: Instead there is this moves, perhaps with ideas of qe5+, but it is much too slow.
moves.30. e7+ Ke8 31. Qc6+ Kf7 32. e8=Q#: And white reaches checkmate via a promotion.  I did feel a bit bad after this win, because there were probably many ways for black to retrieve the game, but in general I had sustained a sacrificial attack from the middlegame.  And in the end, there was some class.
